verses.text: That night, the king could not sleep, so he ordered the book of records, the chronicles, to be brought in, and they were read before the king.
verses.comment: Here, God's providence is at work through apparently ordinary events, showing His subtle intervention in human affairs.

verses.text: It was found written that Mordecai had reported concerning Bigthana and Teresh, two of the king's eunuchs, the doorkeepers, who had sought to lay hands on King Ahasuerus.
verses.comment: This verse recalls Mordecai's earlier faithfulness; God's work is often remembered at just the right moment.

verses.text: The king said, 'What honor or recognition has been bestowed on Mordecai for this?' The king's servants who attended him said, 'Nothing has been done for him.'
verses.comment: God ensures that good deeds are ultimately rewarded. Compare to Matthew 6:4 where secret good is repaid by God.

verses.text: So the king said, 'Who is in the court?' Now Haman had just entered the outer court of the king’s house to speak to the king about hanging Mordecai on the gallows he had prepared for him.
verses.comment: Irony permeates this scene: God uses the plans of the wicked for the good of the righteous (cf. Gen. 50:20).

verses.text: And the king’s servants said to him, 'Look, Haman is standing in the court.' And the king said, 'Let him come in.'
verses.comment: Haman, eager for his plot, enters at God's appointed time, demonstrating God orchestrating events beyond human knowledge.

verses.text: So Haman came in. And the king asked him, 'What should be done for the man whom the king delights to honor?' Now Haman said in his heart, 'Whom would the king delight to honor more than me?'
verses.comment: Haman's pride blinds him (see Prov. 16:18). The passage warns against self-exaltation.

verses.text: And Haman said to the king, 'For the man whom the king delights to honor,'
verses.comment: Haman’s suggestion is meant for himself, but is ultimately used for the humble Mordecai. God exalts the humble (Luke 14:11).

verses.text: 'Let a royal robe be brought which the king has worn, and a horse on which the king has ridden, one having the royal crest on its head.'
verses.comment: The robe and horse suggest deep honor, prefiguring Christ's triumphal entry (Mark 11:7) and His exaltation by the Father.

verses.text: 'Let the robe and the horse be delivered to the hand of one of the king's most noble princes, that they may array the man whom the king delights to honor, then lead him on horseback through the city square, proclaiming before him, “Thus shall it be done to the man whom the king delights to honor!”'
verses.comment: Public honor mirrors the way Christ is exalted after humiliation (cf. Phil. 2:8-9).

verses.text: Then the king said to Haman, 'Hurry! Take the robe and the horse, just as you have said, and do so for Mordecai the Jew, who sits at the king’s gate. Leave out nothing you have said.'
verses.comment: Haman, expecting honor, becomes a servant. God's wisdom overturns human pride (Luke 1:52).

verses.text: So Haman took the robe and the horse, arrayed Mordecai, led him through the city square, and proclaimed before him, 'Thus shall it be done to the man whom the king delights to honor!'
verses.comment: Haman’s humiliation foreshadows the fate of enemies of God's people and all who oppose true servants of God.

verses.text: Afterward, Mordecai returned to the king’s gate, but Haman hurried to his house, mourning and with his head covered.
verses.comment: Mordecai’s return to humble service contrasts with Haman’s shame. This reflects the biblical principle of humility and quiet leadership.

verses.text: And Haman recounted to Zeresh his wife and all his friends everything that had happened to him. His wise men, and Zeresh his wife, said to him, 'If Mordecai, before whom you have begun to fall, is of Jewish descent, you will not overcome him but will surely fall before him.'
verses.comment: Even Haman’s counselors recognize the divine protection over God’s chosen people.

verses.text: While they were still talking with him, the king’s eunuchs arrived and hurried Haman away to the banquet which Esther had prepared.
verses.comment: God’s plan advances rapidly as Haman is brought to his judgment. Banquets often symbolize moments of divine judgment and reversal throughout Scripture.
